It seems no one is checking all this data, resulting on a public database with lots of duplicated items, different nutrition facts for the same item, and misleading info. The developer must create an efficient way for users to report wrong information and remove those items from the database. Bottom line, a really good app if you‚Äôre using your own data.

So if you walked 10 miles in a day, without your heart rate reaching an ‚Äúactive state‚Äù they WILL NOT COUNT IT. Which of course left me with a LOT of calories burned that weren‚Äôt counting on the app so after logging my meals for the day it would turn red and say I‚Äôve eaten over my goal, when in fact I had been eating at too high of a deficit. This is dangerous to eat at too high of a deficit and therefore I find the tracking hazardous. You read that right. You will put your health at risk if you trust this apps calculations. title: Logging is awful
body: The food database is small, and adding foods is painful and likely leads to the inaccuracies other users have complained of. I tried to log a bagel first thing. It wasn't in the database, even though it was from a huge chain with easily accessible nutrition info. To add it, I had to categorize it (either a bread or a roll, imo), enter its mass, and input its macro- and micronutrients. Micronutrients included both salt and sodium (!), which had to be entered in units of grams (!!), and the usual complement of vitamins, minerals, and metals, which had to be entered in mg (!!!). These are ludicrous choices that make one wonder how knowledgeable the app builders are. They also ensure that user-input foods will essentially all have inaccurate data, since people are unlikely to put in the effort to get everything in the units the app wants.
